base

Class ComponentCollection

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.amd.aparapi.Kernel
      • base.ComponentCollection
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConfigurableComponentCollection

    public abstract class ComponentCollection
extends com.amd.aparapi.Kernel

    Base class for all collections of specific types of neural network components to be used in a Simulation. A type of component (e.g. a neuron) is contained in a collection so as to allow off-loading parallel computations to a vector processor (eg GPU) using Aparapi: simulation calculations should be performed on arrays of primitives containing the state variables, inputs and outputs for the components in the collection.

    Rather than extending from this class directly, generally implementations should extend a more specific collection sub-class, such as NeuronCollection or SynapseCollection, which provide some useful functionality and an API for working with that type of component. This allows it to be used alongside other standard collection types and within classes like Simulation.

    The computations for a collection should be performed in the run() method, which overrides the com.amd.aparapi.Kernel run() method. The step() method invokes com.amd.aparapi.Kernel.execute(size*), which invokes the run() method. See the Aparapi documentation for more details, and sub-classes of NeuronCollection and SynapseCollection for examples. For performance reasons, the step() method invokes execute() with sizePower2 rather than the actual size. This means that a sub-class must either:

    1. force the size to be a power of 2; or
    2. add logic to the run() method such that it skips components whose index is >= size; or
    3. Add dummy elements to all component state variable, input and output arrays such that they have length sizePower2.

    It is assumed that the Aparapi kernel is set to use explicit buffer management, meaning that the required arrays/buffers must be sent to and retrieved from the execution hardware (eg GPU) manually using get() and put() (defined in com.amd.aparapi.Kernel) as necessary. Sub-classes of this class, including ConfigurableComponentCollection, NeuronCollection and SynapseCollection, do this for the arrays/buffers they declare, which is one reason that when overriding methods such as init(), reset() and step() the super-method should be invoked from within the overriding method.

    Author:
    Oliver J. Coleman
    See Also:
    Aparapi home page

    • Field Detail

      • size

        protected int size
        The number of components in this collection.

      • sizePower2

        protected int sizePower2
        A number >= to size that is a power of 2.

      • simulation

        protected Simulation simulation
        The containing simulation.

      • localStateVariablesStale

        protected boolean localStateVariablesStale
        Flag to indicate if the state variables used in an Aparapi kernel have been modified on the GPU (and so would need to be transferred back if we're interested in looking at their values). This is only relevant when explicit buffer management is being used.

        public ComponentCollection()

    • Method Detail

      • getSize

        public int getSize()

      • getSimulation

        public Simulation getSimulation()
        Get the containing Simulation.

      • setSimulation

        public void setSimulation(Simulation simulation)
        Set the containing Simulation. Causes this collection to be reinitialised (via init()), and reset (via reset()).

      • init

        public void init()
        Initialise the collection. This method should be called from a sub-classes constructor. Sub-classes should override this method to set the values for pre-calculated values used during the simulation, and call this super-method. Arrays/buffers initialised here and used in the run() method/kernel should be transferred to the execution hardware using put().

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Reset the components to their initial state. Sub-classes should override this method if they have state variables that may be reset to an initial state. Arrays/buffers reset here and used in the run() method/kernel should be transferred to the execution hardware using put().

      • step

        public void step()
        Update the model over one time step. Sub-classes should call this super method. The step() method will invoke the overridden run() method which defines the Aparapi kernel.

      • getStateVariableNames

        public java.lang.String[] getStateVariableNames()
        Get an array containing the names of all the internal state variables. Sub-classes may override this to allow the component to be used for testing or educational purposes.

      • getStateVariableValues

        public double[] getStateVariableValues(int componentIndex)
        Get an array containing the values of all the internal state variables, in the same order as that given by getStateVariableNames(). Sub-classes may override this to allow the component to be used for testing or educational purposes.

      • registerComponentCollectionType

        public static void registerComponentCollectionType(java.lang.String className)
                                            throws java.lang.InstantiationException,
                                                   java.lang.IllegalAccessException,
                                                   java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        Calling this method makes the specified Synapse type available in the list of Synapse types given by getSynapseTypes() and the getSynapseSingleton() method.
        Parameters:
        className - The class of the Synapse type.
